I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA)1 to strengthen the legal and regulatory 
framework of social assistance in the PRC. A TA fact-finding mission, fielded on 9–12 July 2012 
in  Beijing,  discussed  and  agreed  with  the  government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  costs,  financial  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consulting services of the proposed TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A well-functioning social protection system, which ensures the provision of basic needs 
of vulnerable people, is a key factor in attaining inclusive development.3 A core feature of the 
social protection system is social assistance. Social assistance services are provided to target 
beneficiaries  based  on existing  regulations  of the  PRC.  From  1998  when  the government 
accelerated the state-owned enterprise reforms, the PRC economy and society have undergone 
broad changes, including transitions from a rural society to a more urbanized and industrialized 
economy, and from a low-income to a middle-income but more unequal society. There has also 
been significant migration of rural residents to urban centers. These changes have put pressure 
on the social protection system in the PRC to adjust. However, the regulatory framework for 
social  assistance  programs  has  remained  static  and  does  not  ensure  social  services  are 
sufficient or responsive.   
  
3.   Various social assistance programs are being implemented in the PRC, e.g., the urban 
and rural minimum living allowance,4 temporary relief,5 and the rural five guarantees.6 The 
relevant  laws  and  regulations  for  those  social  assistance  programs  are  the  Notice  on 
Establishing the Minimum Living Standard Guarantee for Urban Residence (State Council, 
1997), the Regulations on Urban Minimum Living Standard Guarantee (State Council, 1999), 
                                                
1  The technical assistance (TA) is included in the Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 
2012–2014. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 19 July 2012.  
3  A social protection system focuses on social assistance and two other core factors: (i) social insurance, which 
mitigates risks associated with, among others, unemployment, ill-health, and work-related injuries; and (ii) labor-
market-related issues such as promotion of employment and protection of workers (United Nations Research 
Institute for Social Development. 2010. Combating Poverty and Inequality: Structural Change, Social Policy and 
Politics. Geneva). 
4  The urban minimum living allowance program is for eligible urban residents with nonagricultural permanent 
residence permits. The basic subsistence allowance is provided to those with a per capita income lower than the 
local urban residents’ minimum living standard. The full minimum living allowance is provided to those urban 
residents who have no source of income, no working ability, and no legal guardian to support them (Government of 
the  PRC. 2004. The PRC White Paper. http://english.gov.cn/official/2005-07/28/content_18024.htm). After about 
10 years’ experience in urban areas, the minimum living allowance program was introduced in rural areas in 2007. 
Under the rural minimum living allowance program, subsidies, which vary in different areas depending on the 
economic conditions of the areas, are provided for those whose incomes are below the basic living costs 
(Government  of  the  PRC.  2007.  More  Rural  Residents  to  Benefit  from  Basic  Living  Allowance  System. 
http://www.china.org.cn/english/government/221824.htm). 
5  Temporary relief supplements the minimum living allowance for families which have temporary difficulties or 
families which need further assistance due to special reasons (Ministry of Civil Affairs. 2007. The Notice on Further 
Establishing and Improving Temporary Assistance. Beijing). 
6  The program of rural five guarantees supports elderly rural people who have lost the ability to work, have no source 
of income, and no legal guardians to support them. The program provides elderly people with five guarantees, i.e., 
food, clothing, housing, medical care, and burial expenses (Government of the PRC. 2004. The PRC White Paper. 
http://english.gov.cn/official/2005-07/28/content_18024.htm).

2 
 
the Notice on Establishing Minimum Living Standard Guarantee in Rural Areas (State Council, 
2007), the Notice on Further Establishing and Improving Temporary Assistance (Ministry of Civil 
Affairs, 2007), and the Regulations on the Work of Five Guarantees in Rural Areas (State 
Council, 2006). 
 
4.   There  are  a  number  of  problems  with  the  existing  social  assistance  programs:  (i) 
overlapping coverage and benefits for some portion of poverty population and gaps for others, 
(ii) insufficient level of benefits to help the poor rise out of poverty, and (iii) low quality and 
insufficient provision of social housing support. Expanding the coverage of social assistance to 
the marginal poor7  is also a critical issue in the PRC. Moreover, there is a large disparity in 
social assistance benefits provided to urban registered residents based on the hukou system8 
versus rural residents, and migrant labors who have limited access to social assistance.  
 
5.   To make social assistance effective in the PRC, the efficiency of targeting and the level 
of benefits need to be reassessed. Thus, there is a need to (i) review the legal framework that 
governs social assistance provision in the PRC, and (ii) formulate measures to strengthen the 
legal structure to ensure adequate social assistance for all targeted populations in both urban 
and rural areas and for the migrant population.  
 
6.  The PRC country partnership strategy, 2011–20159 identifies inclusive growth as one of 
the three pillars to foster balanced and equitable development. The key to achieving inclusive 
growth is to build a social protection system that can provide the vulnerable population with 
equitable access to basic social assistance. 
 
7.   The purpose of the TA is to provide the Legislative Affairs Commission of the Standing 
Committee of the National People’s Congress (NPC) with recommendations for streamlining 
and strengthening the legal framework to ensure consistency of policies on social assistance 
provision, focus on the scope of protection, and enhance the level of benefits. 
 
8.   ADB is supporting a number of TA projects related to the PRC social protection system: 
(i) the TA for Building Equitable Opportunities into Social Assistance aims to improve social 
assistance services delivery by ensuring equitable provision of benefits, access to services, and 
capacities  to  deliver  such  services;10  (ii)  the  TA  for  Management  System  and  Legislative 
Mechanism for Nonprofit Organizations focuses on developing a legal framework of nonprofit 
organizations  (NPOs),  including  charity  organizations,  industry  associations,  research 
institutions, and academic societies;11 (iii) the TA for Policy Study on Strategic Options for 
Urbanization assists the PRC in developing a national urban development strategy, including 
affordable housing in urban areas;12 and (iv) the TA for Performance Evaluation Model for the 
                                                
7  The marginal poor are people whose income levels are low but just above the poverty line.  
8  The hukou system officially identifies a person as a resident of an area, which hence segments the population into 
urban and rural. The social protection system in the PRC reflects the distinction between urban and rural 
registration based on the hukou system.

10  ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Building Equitable Opportunities into Social 
Assistance. Manila.  
11  ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Management System and Legislative 
Mechanism for Nonprofit Organizations. Manila. 
12  ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Policy Study on Strategic Options for 
Urbanization. Manila.

3 
 
Urban and Rural Subsistence Social Security focuses on effective implementation of social 
assistance.13  
 
9.  The TA will build on the experiences and lessons learned from these ongoing ADB TAs, 
and focus on the legal framework regulating social assistance programs in the PRC. It is critical 
that  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  is  streamlined  and  strengthened  to  improve  the 
effectiveness and efficiency of social assistance provision in the PRC. The TA will also aim to 
examine and learn from international best practices on social assistance related legal and 
regulatory frameworks, including those covering social assistance programs provided by NPOs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact of the TA will be improved efficiency and effectiveness of social 
assistance,  including  social  housing  support.  The  achievement  of  this  impact  will  be 
demonstrated through a 10% increase in the coverage ratio of the social assistance programs 
for those below the poverty line by 2020. Improving the efficiency of targeting and the scope of 
protection among the social assistance programs will bring about 10% increase in the coverage 
ratio. The data of 2012 will be used as the baseline once the data is released in the last quarter 
of 2012. The expected outcome of the TA will be an improved legal and regulatory framework 
for social assistance, ensuring equitable access of rural, urban, and migrant populations to 
basic  social  assistance  services.  The  achievement  will  be  measured  by  the  adoption  of 
proposed recommendations on legal policies improving social assistance by 2016. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will deliver four major outputs:   
(i)  analysis of the legal and regulatory framework of social assistance in the PRC, 
(ii)  introduction of international best practice on regulation of social assistance that 
ensures equitable access of targeted beneficiaries to basic social assistance 
services, 
(iii)  a policy note including recommendations for streamlining and strengthening the 
legal and regulatory framework of social assistance in the PRC and international 
best practice, and 
(iv)  improved  awareness  of  government  officials  and  other  stakeholders  of  legal 
reforms needed for more equitable and efficient provision of social assistance 
through knowledge products and services 
 
12.  To  complete  the  outputs,  the  following  steps  are  envisaged.  After  recruitment  of 
consultants, the social assistance and welfare law expert consultant (who is also the team 
leader) will develop a detailed work plan in consultation with the Social Law Department of the 
Legislative Affairs Commission at the outset of the TA. The consultants will analyze the current 
status of social assistance in the PRC, covering the urban and rural minimum living allowance, 
temporary relief, the rural five guarantees, and social housing support. The consultants will 
review the legal and regulatory framework of those social assistance programs, and examine 
consistencies  in  regulations  among  those  programs.  Better  coordination  of  NPOs’  charity 
programs with public social assistance is also necessary to improve the efficiency of social 
                                                
13  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Performance Evaluation Model for the 
Urban and Rural Subsistence Social Security. Manila.

4 
 
assistance in the PRC. Thus, the consultants will also examine the issue of charity by NPOs 
with a focus on consistencies in regulation of NPOs with public social assistance in the PRC.  
 
13.  To  learn  from  international  practice,  the  consultant  team  will  analyze  international 
practice on social assistance in the form of comparative study of practice within the PRC and 
international best practice, and produce a policy note summarizing international best practice. 
Based on the analyses, the consultant team will formulate recommendations for streamlining 
and strengthening the legal and regulatory framework for social assistance in the PRC. The 
Social Law Department of the Legislative Affairs Commission will provide the consultants with 
necessary data and background information of current PRC regulations on social assistance 
programs. The Social Law Department of the Legislative Affairs Commission will also provide 
the  consultant  team  with  necessary  support  for  translation  of  background  information  into 
English. 
 
14.  To observe best practices, one or two international study tours will be conducted. In 
addition, to enhance awareness of key issues, build consensus for the reform, and share the 
information, workshops and consultation with government officials and other stakeholders will 
be conducted at various stages of project implementation. This will include an inception or 
interim workshop and a draft final report workshop. All workshops are expected to be attended 
by an ADB mission, government officials, and specialists to ensure the inclusion of diverse 
views and wide dissemination of project outputs. The executing agency will also ensure that all 
finalized reports and recommendations are circulated to all relevant government officials.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  local  office  accommodation,  data,  documents, 
appointments for consultants with relevant agencies and organizations, and other services for 
consultants,  counterpart  staff,  logistics  including  costs  of  selected  translation  and  meeting 
arrangements, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 27 months from 12 October 2012 to 11 December 
2014. The Legislative Affairs Commission of the NPC Standing Committee will be the executing 
agency for the TA. 
17.  The  TA  will  cover  remuneration,  travel,  and  per  diem  of  consultants,  as  well  as 
workshops,  seminars,  study  tours,  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  ADB  will  establish  an 
advanced  payment facility  with  the executing agency to  administer  the  activities  related to 
workshops and study tours, subject to the executing agency’s capacity to complete the activity 
and liquidate the advance. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
18.  There will be five individually recruited consultants: one international social assistance 
and welfare law specialist, as the team leader for 6 person-months, one international NPO and 
charity  organization  specialist  for  2  person-months,  one  national  social  assistance  legal 
specialist for 4 person-months, one national NPO and charitable organization specialist for 2 
person-months, and one national social sector economist for 1.5 person-months. All consultants

5 
 
will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guideline on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference are attached as Appendix 3, with 
deliverables linked to the design and monitoring framework. All reports by the consultants will be 
prepared and provided in both English and Chinese. The consultants will maintain close working 
relations with the executing agency and will regularly discuss project progress and findings.  
 
19.  The executing agency will supervise the day-to-day work of the consultants and take 
responsibility  for  administering  consultation  with  stakeholders,  seminars,  workshops,  and 
international  study  tours.  ADB  will  assist  the  executing  agency  in  overall  TA  operations, 
monitoring, facilitating international study tours, and disseminating knowledge results.  
 
20.  The project-specific indicators and targets in the design and monitoring framework will 
be monitored by the executing agency with ADB support. Policy dialogue will be maintained with 
the government, and project-specific issues will be taken up with government counterparts 
during review missions. Technical milestones will be monitored by reports to be prepared by the 
consultants and reviewed by the executing agency and the project officer.  
 
21.   The  knowledge  products  include  policy  notes  summarizing  recommendations  for 
streamlining and strengthening the legal and regulatory framework of social assistance in the 
PRC and international best practice. The knowledge products will be disseminated through 
seminars, workshops, and other forms such as announcements in government bulletins. These 
activities will be supplemented by media dissemination activities. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of China for  Streamlining Legal  and  Regulatory 
Framework for Social Assistance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10   Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 15.5 person-months of consulting 
services (two international consultants for a total of 8.0 person-months and three national 
consultants for a total of 7.5 person-months). The international consultants should preferably 
have a postgraduate degree or equivalent with about 12 years international experience in their 
respective field of expertise. The national consultants should preferably have a master’s degree 
or equivalent and about 8 years professional experience in their respective field of expertise. 
International consultants will primarily be responsible for introducing international experience 
and  practice,  providing  advisory  services  and  recommendations  to  policy  makers,  and 
disseminating lessons. In addition, the international consultants will serve as peer reviewers on 
reports on technical issues and other documentation translated from Chinese into English. The 
international  consultants  will  review  the  translated  reports  to  ensure  technical  issues  are 
adequately  addressed.  The  international  consultants  will  work  with  national  consultants  in 
cooperation  with  designated  staff  of  the  implementing  agency  to  prepare  reports  and 
recommendations.  National  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  the  technical  aspects  of 
implementing the TA project. 
 
2.  The  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  the  timely  submission  of  TA  outputs  and 
deliverables, and organizing and implementing all TA activities. The consultants will (i) study the 
current legal and regulatory framework of social assistance in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC);  (ii)  assess  relevant  international  best  practice;  (iii)  provide  recommendations  for 
strengthening the legal framework of social assistance service provisions and a policy note 
summarizing  international  best  practice;  (iv)  organize  international  study  tour(s);  and  (v) 
organize  and  participate  in  workshops  or  seminars,  and  prepare  appropriate  presentation 
materials, as necessary. All reports are to be of high quality and produced in English with copies 
in Chinese. Precise work time lines and deliverables with dates will be defined at inception, 
documented in the final inception report, and agreed upon with the executing agency and the 
Asian Development Bank. 
 
A.  International Consultants (8 person-months) 
 
3.  Social assistance and welfare law expert, and team leader (6 person-months). The 
international  expert  should  have  substantial  expertise  and  sufficient  experience  in  social 
assistance and welfare law. He or she must be familiar with social housing support issues and 
the legal framework for social assistance. The expert will  
(i)  work closely with other consultants and the executing agency, and be responsible 
for overall management of the TA implementation;  
(ii)  review the general principles of effective social assistance and the legal framework 
governing  social  assistance  programs,  including  social  housing  support  and 
assistance to migrant populations, in selected developed countries and prepare a 
technical report;  
(iii)  review the current legal framework of social assistance programs both in urban and 
rural areas of the PRC, and prepare a comparative analysis of the regulatory 
framework for social assistance between selected developed countries and the 
PRC  with  a  focus  on  consistencies  in  regulations  between  social  assistance 
programs, and identify areas that need reforms; 
(iv)  prepare and submit recommendations for strengthening the legal and regulatory 
framework of social assistance in the PRC to ensure adequate provision of social 
assistance services for all targeted populations in urban and rural areas and for the

migrant population, with the focus on the consistency of social assistance services, 
the scope of protection, and the level of benefits; 
(v)  produce a policy note summarizing international best practice in social assistance 
including housing and charity issues for ensuring equitable access of targeted 
beneficiaries to basic social assistance services; 
(vi)  lead discussions with the consultants and the executing agency in identifying key 
issues  to  be  covered  during  the  seminars  and  workshops,  identify  resource 
persons, and prepare background materials; 
(vii)  deliver  the  session  at  the  seminar  and/or  workshop  and  prepare  appropriate 
presentation materials; and 
(viii)  lead all TA efforts by guiding, supervising, and coordinating the work of all team 
members; take overall responsibility for preparing and consolidating the reports 
prepared by the team members and submitting all reports, including the inception, 
interim, and final reports, technical reports as well as recommendations and a 
policy note. 
 
4.  Nonprofit organization and charitable organization expert (2 person-months). The 
international expert should have substantial expertise and experience in charity programs by 
nonprofit organizations (NPOs), and must be familiar with the legislative framework governing 
social assistance. The expert will 
(i)  research international practice on NPO charity programs; 
(ii)  examine a mechanism by which the NPOs’ programs can be integrated into the 
social assistance system, and prepare a technical report; 
(iii)  work closely with the other members of the team and the executing agency, and 
provide recommendations to improve the coordination of NPO charity programs 
with public social assistance in the PRC; 
(iv)  assist in identifying key issues to be covered during the seminars and workshops, 
identifying resource persons, and preparing background materials; 
(v)  participate  in  and  assist  during  seminar  and  workshop  sessions  and  prepare 
appropriate presentation materials; and 
(vi)  assist  in  drafting, finalizing,  and  submitting  all reports,  including the  inception, 
interim, and final reports, technical reports as well as recommendations and a 
policy note. 
 
B.  National Consultants (7.5 person-months) 
 
5.  Social assistance legal specialist (4 person-months). The specialist should have good 
knowledge and sufficient professional experience of social assistance legislative regulations and 
policies, including housing support, covering both urban and rural areas of the PRC. The 
specialist will 
(i)  work closely with other members of the team and the executing agency, and take 
the lead in organizing workshops and seminars, conducting international study 
tour(s), and identifying and managing resource persons;  
(ii)  review the current legal framework of social assistance programs both in urban and 
rural  areas  of  the  PRC,  i.e.,  the  urban  and  rural  minimum  living  allowance, 
temporary relief, and the rural five guarantees, and prepare a technical report; 
(iii)  review the current legal framework of social housing support in the PRC; 
(iv)  examine the consistency in regulations among the social assistance programs 
including social housing support, and prepare a technical report;

12  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  assist in preparing a proposal containing the basic underlying principles of social 
assistance, and legal measures to amend the inconsistencies in the legal and 
regulatory framework of social assistance programs in the PRC; 
(vi)  assist in identifying key issues to be covered during the seminars and workshops, 
identify resource persons, and prepare background materials; 
(vii)  participate  in  and  assist  during  seminar  and  workshop  sessions  and  prepare 
appropriate presentation materials; and 
(viii)  assist  in  drafting, finalizing,  and  submitting  all reports,  including the  inception, 
interim, and final reports, technical reports as well as recommendations and a 
policy note. 
 
6.  Nonprofit organization and charitable organization specialist (2 person-months). 
The  specialist  should  have  good  knowledge  and  sufficient  professional  experience  in  the 
implementation of charity programs by NPOs in the PRC. The specialist will 
(i)  review  the  current  status  of  NPO  charity  programs  in  the  PRC,  examine  the 
relationship  between  the  NPOs’  programs  and  public  social  assistance,  and 
prepare a technical report; 
(ii)  work closely with other team members and the executing agency, and provide 
recommendations  on  legal  measures  to  improve  coordination  of  NPO  charity 
programs with public social assistance in the PRC; 
(iii)  assist in preparing a proposal containing the basic underlying principles of social 
assistance,  and  legal  measures  to  amend  inconsistencies  in  the  legal  and 
regulatory framework of social assistance programs in the PRC; 
(iv)  assist in identifying key issues to be covered during the seminars and workshops, 
identify resource persons, and prepare background materials; 
(v)  participate  in  and  assist  during  seminar  and  workshop  sessions  and  prepare 
appropriate presentation materials; and 
(vi)  assist  in  drafting, finalizing,  and  submitting  all reports,  including the  inception, 
interim, and final reports, technical reports as well as recommendations and a 
policy note. 
 
7.  Social  sector  economist  (1.5  person-months).  The  economist  should  have  good 
knowledge and sufficient professional experience in economic and financial analyses of social 
assistance  programs,  particularly  incentive  analysis  and  financial  and  fiscal  implications  of 
social assistance reforms. The economist will 
(i)  review  the  current  economic  incentive  structures  among  the  social  assistance 
programs, i.e., the urban and rural minimum living allowance, temporary relief, and 
the rural five guarantees, and prepare a technical report; 
(ii)  work closely with other members of the team and the executing agency, and 
examine the fiscal implications and economic incentives of reforms in the social 
assistance programs, including estimation of the expected number of beneficiaries 
of the social assistance programs based on the proposed recommendations, and 
prepare a technical report; 
(iii)  assist in preparing a proposal containing the basic underlying principles of social 
assistance,  and  legal  measures  to  amend  inconsistencies  in  the  legal  and 
regulatory framework of social assistance programs in the PRC; 
(iv)  assist in identifying key issues to be covered during the seminars and workshops, 
resource persons, and prepare background materials; 
(v)  participate  in  and  assist  during  seminar  and  workshop  sessions  and  prepare 
appropriate presentation materials; and
